title: Understanding Gibbs Free Energy
text: For a phase to be thermodynamically stable, it should have the lowest Gibbs Free Energy (ΔG) at a given temperature. Remember, $$ΔG=ΔH-TΔS$$. How can you use this equation to determine stability?

title: Calculate Gibbs Free Energy for White Tin
text: Calculate the Gibbs Free Energy: ΔG=ΔH°_f-T*S° using the data for white tin $$(β-form)$$.

title: Calculate Gibbs Free Energy for White Tin
text: Use the provided values: ΔH°_f=0 $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$ and $$S\degree=51.2$$ $$\frac{J}{mol·K}$$ for white tin. At $$298$$ K, calculate ΔG.

title: Calculate Gibbs Free Energy for Gray Tin
text: Next, calculate the Gibbs Free Energy for gray tin $$(\alpha-form)$$ using ΔH°_f and S° values.

title: Calculate Gibbs Free Energy for Gray Tin
text: Use the values: ΔH°_f=-2.12 $$\frac{kJ}{mol}$$ and $$S\degree=44.1$$ $$\frac{J}{mol·K}$$ for gray tin. At $$298$$ K, compute ΔG.

title: Compare Gibbs Free Energies
text: Compare the ΔG values for white tin and gray tin. The phase with the lower ΔG at $$298$$ K will be thermodynamically more stable.
